Diversity-Multiplexing Tradeoff in
Selective-Fading MIMO Channels

Pedro Coronel and Helmut Bölcskei
The first author was previously with IBM Research, Zurich Research Laboratory, Switzerland. This work was supported in part by the STREP project No. IST-026905 MASCOT within the Sixth Framework Programme of the European Commission. Communication Technology Laboratory
ETH Zurich, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland
E-mail: {pco, boelcskei}@nari.ee.ethz.ch
Abstract

We establish the optimal diversity-multiplexing (DM) tradeoff of coherent time, frequency and time-frequency selective-fading MIMO channels and provide a code design criterion for DM-tradeoff optimality. Our results are based on the analysis of the “Jensen channel” associated to a given selective-fading MIMO channel. While the original problem seems analytically intractable due to the mutual information being a sum of correlated random variables, the Jensen channel is equivalent to the original channel in the sense of the DM-tradeoff and lends itself nicely to analytical treatment. Finally, as a consequence of our results, we find that the classical rank criterion for space-time code design (in selective-fading MIMO channels) ensures optimality in the sense of the DM-tradeoff.

I Introduction

The diversity-multiplexing (DM) tradeoff framework introduced by Zheng and Tse [1] allows to efficiently characterize the information-theoretic performance limits of communication over multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) fading channels. In addition, the results in [1] have triggered significant activity on the design of DM-tradeoff optimal space-time codes. In particular, the non-vanishing determinant criterion [2, 3] on codeword difference matrices has been shown to constitute a sufficient condition for DM-tradeoff optimality in flat-fading MIMO channels with two transmit and two or more receive antennas [3]; this criterion has led to the construction of space-time codes based on constellation rotation [3, 4] and cyclic division algebras [5]. In [6] lattice-based space-time codes have been shown to be DM-tradeoff optimal. The DM-tradeoff optimality of approximately universal space-time codes was established in [7].

Contributions: While the results mentioned above focus on frequency-flat block-fading channels, extensions to frequency-selective channels can be found in [8, 9]. However, a general characterization of the optimal DM-tradeoff in time, frequency or time-frequency selective-fading MIMO channels, in the following simply referred to as selective-fading MIMO channels, remains an open problem. The present paper resolves this problem for the coherent case (i.e., for perfect channel state information (CSI) at the receiver) and provides a code design criterion guaranteeing DM-tradeoff optimality. Our results are based on exponentially tight (in the sense of exhibiting the same DM-tradeoff behavior) upper and lower bounds on the mutual information of (coherent) selective-fading MIMO channels. In particular, we show that the DM-tradeoff of this class of channels can be obtained by solving the analytically tractable problem of computing the DM-tradeoff curve corresponding to the associated “Jensen channel”.

III Diversity-multiplexing tradeoff

III-A Preliminaries

Unlike the frequency-flat fading case treated in [1], characterizing d𝒪​(r)subscript𝑑𝒪𝑟d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r) for the selective-fading case seems analytically intractable with the main difficulty stemming from the fact that one has to deal with the sum of correlated (recall that the 𝐇nsubscript𝐇𝑛\mathbf{H}_{n} are correlated across n𝑛n) terms in (4). It turns out, however, that one can find lower and upper bounds on I​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)I𝖲𝖭𝖱\mathrm{I}(\mathsf{SNR}) which are exponentially tight (and, hence, preserve the DM-tradeoff behavior) and analytically tractable. The next section formalizes this idea.

III-B Jensen channel and Jensen outage event

We start by noting that applying Jensen’s inequality yields

I​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)=1N​∑n=0N−1log​det(𝐈MR+𝖲𝖭𝖱MT​𝐇n​𝐇nH)≤log​det(𝐈m+𝖲𝖭𝖱MT​N​𝓗𝓗H):=J​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)I𝖲𝖭𝖱1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝑁1subscript𝐈subscriptMR𝖲𝖭𝖱subscriptMTsubscript𝐇𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐇𝑛𝐻subscript𝐈m𝖲𝖭𝖱subscriptMT𝑁superscript𝓗𝓗𝐻assignJ𝖲𝖭𝖱\mathrm{I}(\mathsf{SNR})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\log\det\negthinspace\left(\mathbf{I}_{\mathrm{M_{R}}}+\frac{\mathsf{SNR}}{\mathrm{M_{T}}}\mathbf{H}_{n}\mathbf{H}_{n}^{H}\right)\leq\\ \log\det\mathopen{}\left(\mathbf{I}_{\mathrm{m}}+\frac{\mathsf{SNR}}{\mathrm{M_{T}}N}{\mbox{\boldmath{$\mathcal{H}$}}}{\mbox{\boldmath{$\mathcal{H}$}}}^{H}\right):=\mathrm{J}(\mathsf{SNR}) (7)

where the “Jensen channel” is defined as

𝓗={[𝐇0​𝐇1​…​𝐇N−1],if MR≤MT,[𝐇0H​𝐇1H​…​𝐇N−1H],if MR>MT.𝓗casesdelimited-[]subscript𝐇0subscript𝐇1…subscript𝐇𝑁1if MR≤MT,delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐇0𝐻superscriptsubscript𝐇1𝐻…superscriptsubscript𝐇𝑁1𝐻if MR>MT.{\mbox{\boldmath{$\mathcal{H}$}}}=\begin{cases}\;[\mathbf{H}_{0}\;\mathbf{H}_{1}\;\ldots\;\mathbf{H}_{N-1}],&\text{if $\mathrm{M_{R}}\leq\mathrm{M_{T}}$,}\\ [\mathbf{H}_{0}^{H}\;\mathbf{H}_{1}^{H}\;\ldots\;\mathbf{H}_{N-1}^{H}],&\text{if $\mathrm{M_{R}}>\mathrm{M_{T}}$.}\end{cases}

In the following, we say that a Jensen outage event occurs if the Jensen channel 𝓗𝓗\mathcal{H} is in outage w.r.t. the rate R​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)=r​log⁡𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑅𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱R(\mathsf{SNR})=r\log\mathsf{SNR}, i.e., if J​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)<R​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)J𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑅𝖲𝖭𝖱\mathrm{J}(\mathsf{SNR})<R(\mathsf{SNR}). The corresponding outage probability will be denoted as P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR}) and clearly satisfies P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤P𝒪​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝒪𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\leq P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r,\mathsf{SNR}). The operational significance of a Jensen outage will be established at the end of this section. We shall first focus on characterizing the Jensen outage event analytically. and note that P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≐ℙ​(𝒥​(r))approaches-limitsubscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱ℙ𝒥𝑟P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\doteq\mathbb{P}\left(\mathcal{J}(r)\right), where

𝒥​(r)={𝜶∈ℝ+m:α1≥α2≥…≥αm,∑k=1m[1−αk]+<r}.𝒥𝑟conditional-set𝜶superscriptsubscriptℝmformulae-sequencesubscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼msuperscriptsubscript𝑘1msuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscript𝛼𝑘𝑟\displaystyle\mathcal{J}(r)=\mathopen{}\left\{\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\mathrm{m}}\negthickspace:\alpha_{1}\negthinspace\geq\negthinspace\alpha_{2}\negthinspace\geq\negthinspace\ldots\negthinspace\geq\negthinspace\alpha_{\mathrm{m}},\sum_{k=1}^{\mathrm{m}}[1-\alpha_{k}]^{+}<r\right\}.

It is now natural to define the Jensen outage curve as

d𝒥​(r)=−lim𝖲𝖭𝖱→∞log⁡P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)log⁡𝖲𝖭𝖱.subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟subscript→𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱𝖲𝖭𝖱\displaystyle d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r)=-\lim_{\mathsf{SNR}\rightarrow\infty}\frac{\log P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})}{\log\mathsf{SNR}}.

Based on (10), we can conclude that d𝒥​(r)subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r) is nothing but the DM-tradeoff curve of an effective MIMO channel with ρ​M𝜌M\rho\mathrm{M} transmit and mm\mathrm{m} receive antennas. We can therefore directly apply the results in [1] to infer that the Jensen outage curve is the piecewise linear function connecting the points (r,d𝒥​(r))𝑟subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟(r,d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r)) for r=0,1,…,m𝑟01…mr=0,1,\ldots,\mathrm{m}, with

d𝒥​(r)=(ρ​M−r)​(m−r).subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟𝜌M𝑟m𝑟d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r)=(\rho\mathrm{M}-r)(\mathrm{m}-r). (12)

Since, as already noted, P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤P𝒪​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝒪𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\leq P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r,\mathsf{SNR}), we obtain

d𝒞​(r)≤d⋆​(r)≤d𝒪​(r)≤d𝒥​(r),r∈[0,m],formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝒞𝑟superscript𝑑⋆𝑟subscript𝑑𝒪𝑟subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟𝑟0md_{\mathcal{C}}(r)\leq d^{\star}\mspace{-2.0mu}(r)\leq d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r)\leq d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r),\quad r\in[0,\mathrm{m}], (13)

for any family of codes 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}. The optimal DM-tradeoff curve d⋆​(r)superscript𝑑⋆𝑟d^{\star}\mspace{-2.0mu}(r) will be established in the next section by showing that codes satisfying d𝒞​(r)=d𝒥​(r)subscript𝑑𝒞𝑟subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟d_{\mathcal{C}}(r)=d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r) do exist and hence d⋆​(r)=d𝒥​(r)superscript𝑑⋆𝑟subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟d^{\star}\mspace{-2.0mu}(r)=d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r).

IV Jensen-optimal code design criterion

The goal of this section is to derive a sufficient condition for a family of codes to achieve d𝒥​(r)subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r), and hence, by virtue of (13), to be DM-tradeoff optimal.

IV-A Code design criterion

Theorem 1

Consider a family of codes 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} with block length N≥ρ​MT𝑁𝜌subscriptMTN\geq\rho\mathrm{M_{T}} that operates over the channel (1). If, for any codebook 𝒞r​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)∈𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}(\mathsf{SNR})\in\mathcal{C}_{r} and any two codewords 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, 𝐗′∈𝒞r​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)superscript𝐗′subscript𝒞𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C}_{r}(\mathsf{SNR}), the codeword difference matrix 𝐄=𝐗−𝐗′𝐄𝐗superscript𝐗′\mathbf{E}=\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime} is such that

rank​(𝐑ℍ⊙𝐄H​𝐄)=ρ​MTrankdirect-productsubscript𝐑ℍsuperscript𝐄𝐻𝐄𝜌subscriptMT\mathrm{rank}\negthinspace\left(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{H}}\odot\mathbf{E}^{H}\mathbf{E}\right)=\rho\mathrm{M_{T}} (14)

(16)

=∑k=1mλk​(𝓗¯w​𝓗¯wH)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1msubscript𝜆𝑘subscript¯𝓗𝑤superscriptsubscript¯𝓗𝑤𝐻\displaystyle=\;\sum_{k=1}^{\mathrm{m}}\lambda_{k}(\overline{\mbox{\boldmath{$\mathcal{H}$}}}_{\mspace{-2.0mu}w}\overline{\mbox{\boldmath{$\mathcal{H}$}}}_{\mspace{-2.0mu}w}^{H})
=∑k=1m𝖲𝖭𝖱−αkabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1msuperscript𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝛼𝑘\displaystyle=\;\sum_{k=1}^{\mathrm{m}}\mathsf{SNR}^{-\alpha_{k}} (17)

where (17) follows from (11). We can now write the PEP upper-bound in (16) in terms of the singularity levels αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} (k=1,2,…,m𝑘12…mk\negmedspace=\negmedspace 1,2,\ldots,\mathrm{m}) characterizing the Jensen outage event:

(18)

The dependence of the PEP upper bound (20) on the singularity levels characterizing the Jensen outage event suggests to split up the overall error probability according to

Pe​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)subscript𝑃𝑒𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱\displaystyle P_{e}(r,\mathsf{SNR}) =ℙ​(error,𝜶∈𝒥​(r))+ℙ​(error,𝜶∉𝒥​(r))absentℙerror𝜶𝒥𝑟ℙerror𝜶𝒥𝑟\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error},\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\in\mathcal{J}(r)\right)+\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error},\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right)
=ℙ​(𝜶∈𝒥​(r))​ℙ​(error|𝜶∈𝒥​(r))absentℙ𝜶𝒥𝑟ℙconditionalerror𝜶𝒥𝑟\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}\left(\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\in\mathcal{J}(r)\right)\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error}|\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\in\mathcal{J}(r)\right)
+ℙ​(𝜶∉𝒥​(r))​ℙ​(error|𝜶∉𝒥​(r))ℙ𝜶𝒥𝑟ℙconditionalerror𝜶𝒥𝑟\displaystyle{\hskip 19.91692pt}+\mathbb{P}\left(\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right)\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error}|\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right)

+ℙ​(𝜶∉𝒥​(r))​ℙ​(error|𝜶∉𝒥​(r)).ℙ𝜶𝒥𝑟ℙconditionalerror𝜶𝒥𝑟\displaystyle{\hskip 19.91692pt}+\mathbb{P}\left(\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right)\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error}|\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right). (21)

For any 𝜶∉𝒥​(r)𝜶𝒥𝑟\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r), we have ∑k=1m[1−αk]+≥rsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1msuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscript𝛼𝑘𝑟\sum_{k=1}^{\mathrm{m}}[1-\alpha_{k}]^{+}\geq r and |𝒮|≥1𝒮1|\mathcal{S}|\geq 1, which upon noting that |𝒞r​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)|=𝖲𝖭𝖱N​rsubscript𝒞𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑁𝑟|\mathcal{C}_{r}(\mathsf{SNR})|=\mathsf{SNR}^{Nr}, yields the following union bound based on the PEP in (20)

ℙ​(error|𝜶∉𝒥​(r))ℙconditionalerror𝜶𝒥𝑟\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error}|\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right) ≤𝖲𝖭𝖱N​r​exp⁡(−λ4​MT​𝖲𝖭𝖱r/m)absentsuperscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑁𝑟𝜆4subscriptMTsuperscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑟m\displaystyle\leq\mathsf{SNR}^{Nr}\exp{\left(-\frac{\lambda}{4\mathrm{M_{T}}}\>\mathsf{SNR}^{r/\mathrm{m}}\right)}

where we used |𝒮|≤m𝒮m|\mathcal{S}|\leq\mathrm{m}. Hence, for any r>0𝑟0r>0, ℙ​(error|𝜶∉𝒥​(r))ℙconditionalerror𝜶𝒥𝑟\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error}|\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right) decays exponentially in SNR and we have

ℙ​(error,𝜶∉𝒥​(r))ℙerror𝜶𝒥𝑟\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error},\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right) =ℙ​(𝜶∉𝒥​(r))⏟≤1​ℙ​(error|𝜶∉𝒥​(r))absentsubscript⏟ℙ𝜶𝒥𝑟absent1ℙconditionalerror𝜶𝒥𝑟\displaystyle=\underbrace{\mathbb{P}\left(\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right)}_{\leq 1}\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error}|\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right)
≤𝖲𝖭𝖱N​r​exp⁡(−λ4​MT​𝖲𝖭𝖱r/m).absentsuperscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑁𝑟𝜆4subscriptMTsuperscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑟m\displaystyle\leq\mathsf{SNR}^{Nr}\exp{\left(-\frac{\lambda}{4\mathrm{M_{T}}}\>\mathsf{SNR}^{r/\mathrm{m}}\right)}. (22)

Consequently, noting that ℙ​(𝜶∈𝒥​(r))≐P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)approaches-limitℙ𝜶𝒥𝑟subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱\mathbb{P}\left(\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\in\mathcal{J}(r)\right)\doteq P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR}) and using (IV-A) in (21), we obtain

Pe​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤˙P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱).˙subscript𝑃𝑒𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{e}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\mathrel{\dot{\leq}}P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR}).

Since P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤P𝒪​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝒪𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\leq P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r,\mathsf{SNR}), it follows trivially that P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤˙P𝒪​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)˙subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝒪𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\mathrel{\dot{\leq}}P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r,\mathsf{SNR}). In addition, for a specific family of codes 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}, we have P𝒪​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤Pe​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)subscript𝑃𝒪𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝑒𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\leq P_{e}(r,\mathsf{SNR}) and hence P𝒪​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤˙Pe​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)˙subscript𝑃𝒪𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝑒𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\mathrel{\dot{\leq}}P_{e}(r,\mathsf{SNR}). Putting the pieces together, we finally obtain

P𝒪​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤˙Pe​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤˙P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≤˙P𝒪​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)˙subscript𝑃𝒪𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝑒𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱˙subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱˙subscript𝑃𝒪𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\mathrel{\dot{\leq}}P_{e}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\mathrel{\dot{\leq}}P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\mathrel{\dot{\leq}}P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle O}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})

which implies

Pe​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≐P𝒥​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)approaches-limitsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑃𝒥𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱P_{e}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\doteq P_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r,\mathsf{SNR})

and hence (by definition of d𝒥​(r)subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r))

Pe​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≐𝖲𝖭𝖱−d𝒥​(r).approaches-limitsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟P_{e}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\doteq\mathsf{SNR}^{-d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r)}.

∎

As a direct consequence of Theorem 1, a family of codes that satisfies (14) for all codeword difference matrices in any codebook 𝒞r​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)∈𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}(\mathsf{SNR})\in\mathcal{C}_{r} realizes a DM-tradeoff curve d𝒞​(r)=d𝒥​(r)subscript𝑑𝒞𝑟subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟d_{\mathcal{C}}(r)=d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r) and hence, by (13)

d𝒥​(r)≤d⋆​(r)≤d𝒥​(r)subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟superscript𝑑⋆𝑟subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r)\leq d^{\star}\mspace{-2.0mu}(r)\leq d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r)

which implies

d⋆​(r)=d𝒥​(r).superscript𝑑⋆𝑟subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟d^{\star}\mspace{-2.0mu}(r)=d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r). (23)

The optimal DM-tradeoff curve for selective-fading MIMO channels is therefore given by the DM-tradeoff curve of the associated Jensen channel. Put differently, Theorem 1 shows that, even though 𝒥​(r)⊆𝒪​(r)𝒥𝑟𝒪𝑟\mathcal{J}(r)\subseteq\mathcal{O}(r) by definition, we still have

ℙ​(𝒥​(r))≐ℙ​(𝒪​(r))approaches-limitℙ𝒥𝑟ℙ𝒪𝑟\mathbb{P}\left(\mathcal{J}(r)\right)\doteq\mathbb{P}\left(\mathcal{O}(r)\right)

which essentially says that the “original” channel has the same high-SNR outage behavior as its associated Jensen channel.

The code design criterion in Theorem 1 provides a sufficient condition for achieving the DM-tradeoff curve. Interestingly, the classical rank criterion [13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18], aimed at maximizing the diversity gain for r=0𝑟0r=0, can be shown [19] to be equivalent to the criterion in Theorem 1. We emphasize, however, that optimality w.r.t. the DM-tradeoff at multiplexing rate r𝑟r requires that (14) is satisfied for all codeword difference matrices in any codebook 𝒞r​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)∈𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}(\mathsf{SNR})\in\mathcal{C}_{r}, in particular also for 𝖲𝖭𝖱→∞→𝖲𝖭𝖱\mathsf{SNR}\rightarrow\infty. We next state a sufficient condition for DM-tradeoff optimality which makes this aspect explicit and establishes a connection to the approximately universal code design criterion in [7].

Corollary 1

A family of codes 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} of block length N≥ρ​MT𝑁𝜌subscriptMTN\geq\rho\mathrm{M_{T}} is DM-tradeoff optimal if there exists an ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 such that

λm​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)≥˙𝖲𝖭𝖱−(r−ϵ)˙superscript𝜆m𝖲𝖭𝖱superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑟italic-ϵ\lambda^{\mathrm{m}}(\mathsf{SNR})\mathrel{\dot{\geq}}\mathsf{SNR}^{-(r-\epsilon)} (24)

where

λ​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)=mink=1,2,…,ρ​MT𝐄=𝐗−𝐗′,𝐗,𝐗′∈𝒞r​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)⁡{λk​(𝐑ℍ⊙𝐄H​𝐄)>0}.𝜆𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑘12…𝜌subscriptMTformulae-sequence𝐄𝐗superscript𝐗′𝐗superscript𝐗′subscript𝒞𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝜆𝑘direct-productsubscript𝐑ℍsuperscript𝐄𝐻𝐄0\lambda(\mathsf{SNR})=\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}k=1,2,\ldots,\rho\mathrm{M_{T}}\\ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime},\>\mathbf{X},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C}_{r}(\mathsf{SNR})\end{subarray}}\bigg{\{}\lambda_{k}(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{H}}\odot\mathbf{E}^{H}\mathbf{E})>0\bigg{\}}.
Proof:

Using (24) in (IV-A), we obtain

ℙ​(error,𝜶∉𝒥​(r))≤𝖲𝖭𝖱N​r​exp⁡(−𝖲𝖭𝖱ϵ/m4​MT)ℙerror𝜶𝒥𝑟superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑁𝑟superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱italic-ϵm4subscriptMT\mathbb{P}\left(\mathrm{error},\mbox{\boldmath{$\alpha$}}\notin\mathcal{J}(r)\right)\leq\mathsf{SNR}^{Nr}\exp{\left(-\frac{\mathsf{SNR}^{\epsilon/\mathrm{m}}}{4\mathrm{M_{T}}}\right)}

which, following the same logic as in the proof of Theorem 1, implies that Pe​(r,𝖲𝖭𝖱)≐𝖲𝖭𝖱−d𝒥​(r)approaches-limitsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑑𝒥𝑟P_{e}(r,\mathsf{SNR})\doteq\mathsf{SNR}^{-d_{\mathcal{\scriptscriptstyle J}}(r)}. ∎

Note that the quantity λm​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)superscript𝜆m𝖲𝖭𝖱\lambda^{\mathrm{m}}(\mathsf{SNR}) is trivially a lower bound on the product of the mm\mathrm{m} smallest nonzero eigenvalues of any codeword difference matrix in the codebook 𝒞r​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)subscript𝒞𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱\mathcal{C}_{r}(\mathsf{SNR}). Consequently, in the case of non-selective fading, where 𝐑ℍ⊙𝐄H​𝐄=𝐄H​𝐄direct-productsubscript𝐑ℍsuperscript𝐄𝐻𝐄superscript𝐄𝐻𝐄\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{H}}\odot\mathbf{E}^{H}\mathbf{E}=\mathbf{E}^{H}\mathbf{E}, any family of codes 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} satisfying (24) will also be approximately universal in the sense of [7, Th. 3.1]. Moreover, if λ​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)𝜆𝖲𝖭𝖱\lambda(\mathsf{SNR}) remains strictly positive as 𝖲𝖭𝖱→∞→𝖲𝖭𝖱\mathsf{SNR}\rightarrow\infty, 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} fulfills the non-vanishing determinant criterion [2, 3] and will, by (IV-A) and the same arguments as in the proof of Theorem 1, be DM-tradeoff optimal.

IV-B Application to the frequency-selective case

As an example, we shall next specialize our results to frequency-selective fading MIMO channels, recovering the results reported previously in [8, 9]. For the sake of simplicity of exposition, we shall employ a cyclic signal model, as obtained in an OFDM system for example. The channel’s transfer function is given by

𝐇​(ej​2​π​θ)=∑l=0L−1𝐇​(l)​e−j​2​π​l​θ,0≤θ<1formulae-sequence𝐇superscript𝑒𝑗2𝜋𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿1𝐇𝑙superscript𝑒𝑗2𝜋𝑙𝜃0𝜃1\mathbf{H}(e^{j2\pi\theta})=\sum_{l=0}^{L-1}\mathbf{H}(l)\>e^{-j2\pi l\theta},\quad 0\leq\theta<1

where the 𝐇​(l)𝐇𝑙\mathbf{H}(l) have i.i.d. 𝒞​𝒩​(0,σl2)𝒞𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙2\mathcal{CN}\negthinspace\left(0,\sigma_{l}^{2}\right) entries and satisfy

𝔼​{vec​(𝐇​(l))​vec​(𝐇​(l′))H}=σl2​δ​(l−l′)​𝐈MT​MR.𝔼vec𝐇𝑙vecsuperscript𝐇superscript𝑙′𝐻superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙2𝛿𝑙superscript𝑙′subscript𝐈subscriptMTsubscriptMR\mathbb{E}\negthinspace\left\{\mathrm{vec}\negthinspace\left(\mathbf{H}(l)\right)\mathrm{vec}\negthinspace\left(\mathbf{H}(l^{\prime})\right)^{H}\right\}=\sigma_{l}^{2}\>\delta(l-l^{\prime})\>\mathbf{I}_{\mathrm{M_{T}}\mathrm{M_{R}}}.

With 𝐇n=𝐇​(ej​2​π​nN)subscript𝐇𝑛𝐇superscript𝑒𝑗2𝜋𝑛𝑁\mathbf{H}_{n}=\mathbf{H}(e^{j2\pi\frac{n}{N}}), n=0,1​…,N−1𝑛01…𝑁1n\negmedspace=\negmedspace 0,1\ldots,N-1, the channel’s covariance matrix follows as

𝐑ℍ=𝐅​diag​{σ02,σ12,…,σL−12,0,…,0}​𝐅Hsubscript𝐑ℍ𝐅diagsuperscriptsubscript𝜎02superscriptsubscript𝜎12…superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐿120…0superscript𝐅𝐻\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{H}}=\mathbf{F}\>\mathrm{diag}\negthinspace\left\{\sigma_{0}^{2},\sigma_{1}^{2},\ldots,\sigma_{L-1}^{2},0,\ldots,0\right\}\mathbf{F}^{H}

where 𝐅𝐅\mathbf{F} is the N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N FFT matrix. Since rank​(𝐑ℍ)=Lranksubscript𝐑ℍ𝐿\mathrm{rank}\negthinspace\left(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{H}}\right)=L, inserting ρ=L𝜌𝐿\rho=L into (12) and using (23) yields the optimal DM-tradeoff curve as the piecewise linear function connecting the points (r,d⋆​(r))𝑟superscript𝑑⋆𝑟(r,d^{\star}\mspace{-2.0mu}(r)) for r=0,1,…,m𝑟01…mr=0,1,\ldots,\mathrm{m}, with

d⋆​(r)=(L​M−r)​(m−r).superscript𝑑⋆𝑟𝐿M𝑟m𝑟d^{\star}\mspace{-2.0mu}(r)=(L\mathrm{M}-r)(\mathrm{m}-r). (25)

This is the optimal DM-tradeoff curve for frequency-selective fading MIMO channels reported previously in [9]. Specializing (25) to the case MT=MR=1subscriptMTsubscriptMR1\mathrm{M_{T}}\negthinspace=\negthinspace\mathrm{M_{R}}\negthinspace=\negthinspace 1 and noting that d⋆​(r)=(L−r)​(1−r)=L​(1−r)superscript𝑑⋆𝑟𝐿𝑟1𝑟𝐿1𝑟d^{\star}\mspace{-2.0mu}(r)=(L-r)(1-r)=L(1-r) for r={0,1}𝑟01r=\{0,1\}, yields the results reported in [8]. We note that the proof techniques employed in [8, 9] are different from the approach taken in this paper and seem to be tailored to the frequency-selective case. In addition, our approach is not limited to large code lengths as (14) can be guaranteed for any N≥L​MT𝑁𝐿subscriptMTN\geq L\mathrm{M_{T}}.

V Conclusions

Analyzing the high-SNR outage behavior of the Jensen channel instead of the original channel was found to be an effective tool to establish the DM-tradeoff in selective-fading MIMO channels. We showed that satisfying extensions (to the selective-fading MIMO case) of the approximately universal code design criterion [7] and the non-vanishing determinant criterion [2, 3] results in DM-tradeoff optimal codes. Finally, we note that the concepts introduced in this paper can be extended to multiple-access selective-fading MIMO channels and to the analysis of the DM-tradeoff properties of specific (suboptimal) receivers.
